Award.AwardTitle: A New Era in Ground-Based Optical Aeronomy at Millstone Hill
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will study the dynamics of the mesosphere and thermosphere using advanced optical instrumentation at the Millstone Hill Observatory in Massachusetts. This is a multi-institution collaborative effort involving Boston University (BU), the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), Scientific Solutions Incorporated (SSI), and the MIT staff at Millstone Hill. The combined imaging, intensity, temperature and wind measurements will yield important new insights in several areas: how gravity wave propagation characteristics governs energy and momentum deposition rates in the region, the formation mechanisms and behavior of the large-scale density gradients and traveling atmospheric disturbances observed within the ionosphere/thermosphere system, and their relationship to geomagnetic storms and space weather. In addition, the upward coupling processes and mechanisms responsible for energy and momentum transport between the mesosphere and thermosphere will be a central area of study. Several thermospheric emissions at three different height regimes in the ~95-300 km region will, for the first time, be measured during both the night and daytime to provide a continuous 24-hour series of measurements. The measurements will be obtained with a new multi-wavelength daytime echelle spectrograph designed and built at Boston University. The continuous measurements will provide uninterrupted time histories of several large-scale dynamical processes, such as gravity wave activity, tides, planetary waves, traveling atmospheric disturbances, Stable Auroral Red arcs, and aurora, over the entire altitude range of the mesosphere and thermosphere. The new spectrograph is a prelude to a future daytime imaging Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) which will yield 24-hour coverage of neutral temperatures and winds. In addition, a major refurbishment of the two existing Fabry-Perot Interferometers, will provide optical wind and temperature measurements from three altitude regions (87 km, 96 km, and 250 km) in the mesosphere and thermosphere. The datasets obtained from this work will be made available at www.buimaging.com in the form of quick-look images, movies, and temperature data. They will also be submitted to the CEDAR and MADRIGAL databases. In an effort to involve the wider aeronomy community, the investigators will host guest observing and/or instrument programs at Millstone during each season and will provide assistance to interested users. As part of the public observing nights program at the Boston University roof observatory, the investigators will present several talks on the Earth's upper atmosphere, its composition, dynamics, and daily and seasonal variations, and how the Earth relates to the other planets in the solar system.

Project Outcomes Report for NSF award ATM-0724440

 

A New Era in Ground-Based Optical Aeronomy at Millstone Hill

 

The major goal of the project was to re-establish the optical aeronomy research effort at Millstone Hill after a period of decline. The facility is located at the Haystack Observatory, Massachusetts, where the NSF-funded Millstone Hill incoherent scatter radar resides.

 

Specifically, project proposed the design, refurbishment, and installation of a number of

research instruments to investigate and understand several unresolved questions regarding the structure and dynamics of the earth’s upper atmosphere from 80 km to over 500 km altitude. A high-resolution daytime-night-time spectrograph was designed and built to record emission data over a continuous 24-hour period. An existing multi-spectral all-sky imaging system and a hydroxyl (OH) temperature imaging spectrograph were also refurbished.

 

During the term of this project, we have collaborated with a number of individuals and institutions.

 

An undergraduate student was hired during the project. As well as learning about the dynamics and processes that occur in the upper atmosphere, they also wrote and developed software to reduce and analyze the data.

 

We investigated the ionospheric effects due to a rocket launch over Millstone Hill and found that a 75% decrease in ionospheric TEC due the rocket exhaust.

Mendillo, M., S.M. Smith, A. Coster, P. Erickson, J. Baumgardner, and C. Martinis (2008), Man-Made Space Weather, Space Weather.

 

A comparison of ground-based OH rotational temperatures obtained with the OH temperature spectrograph with TIMED SABER temperatures during overpasses of Millstone Hill yielded excellent agreement with the mean difference being -1.8 ± 5.7 K.

Smith, S.M., J. Baumgardner, C.J. Mertens, J.M. Russell, M.G. Mlynczak, and M. Mendillo (2009), Ground-based mesospheric OH temperature comparisons with simultaneous TIMED SABER temperatures over Millstone Hill, J. Adv. Space Res.

 

We also collaborated in a wider global comparison of SABER temperature measurements:

Lopez-Gonzalez, M.J., E. Rodriguez, M. Lopez-Puertas, M. Garcia-Comas, M.G. Shepherd, G.G. Shepherd, S. Sargoytchev, V.M. Aushec, S.M. Smith, M.G. Mlynczak, J.M. Russell, S. Brown, Y.M. Cho, and R.H. Wein (2007), Ground-based mesospheric temperatures at mid-latitude derived from O2 and OH airglow SATI data: Comparison with SABER measurements, J. Atmos.and Solar Terr. Phys.

 

Measurements from the new daytime spectrograph yielded the world’s first continuous 24-hour measurements of 557.7 nm and 630.0 nm dayglow over Millstone Hill from a ground-based spectrograph.

Marshall, R.A., S.M. Smith, J. Baumgardner, and S. Chakrabarti (2011), Continuous Ground-based Multi-wavelength Airglow Measurements, J. Geophys. Res.

 

We discovered a strong seasonal correlation between OH temperature and brightness, suggesting that seasonal variations in atomic oxygen in the MLT region (80-100 km altitude) are extremely important to the dynamics and photochemistry of this poorly-understood region of the earth’s atmosphere.

Smith, S.M. (2012), Seasonal Variations in the Correlation between Mesospheric OH Temperature and Radiance, J. Geophys. Res.
